messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learned k-NN Distance Estimation

Paper Abstract: Abstract. Big data mining is well known to be an important task for data science, because it can provide useful observations and new knowledge hidden in given large datasets. Proximity-based data analysis is particularly utilized in many real-life applications. In such analysis, the distances to kùëòk nearest neighbors are usually employed, thus its main bottleneck is derived from data retrieval. Much efforts have been made to improve the efficiency of these analyses. However, they still incur large costs, because they essentially need many data accesses. To avoid this issue, we propose a machine-learning technique that quickly and accurately estimates the kùëòk-NN distances (i.e., distances to the kùëòk nearest neighbors) of a given query. We train a fully connected neural network model and utilize pivots to achieve accurate estimation. Our model is designed to have useful advantages: it infers distances to the kùëòk-NNs at a time, its inference time is O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) (no data accesses are incurred), but it keeps high accuracy. Our experimental results and case studies on real datasets demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of our solution.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learned k-NN Distance Estimation",
        "Fast Density-Peaks Clustering: Multicore-based Parallelization Approach",
        "Fast and Exact Outlier Detection in Metric Spaces: A Proximity Graph-based Approach",
        "Fast, Exact, and Parallel-friendly Outlier Detection Algorithms with Proximity Graph in Metric Spaces",
        "DOLPHIN: An Efficient Algorithm for Mining Distance-based Outliers in Very Large Datasets",
        "Parameterized machine learning for high-energy physics",
        "Mining Distance-based Outliers in Near Linear Time with Randomization and a Simple Pruning Rule",
        "Multidimensional Binary Search Trees Used for Associative Searching",
        "Cover trees for Nearest Neighbor",
        "A Weighted k-Nearest Neighbor Density Estimate for Geometric Inference",
        "Outlier Detection: Methods, Models, and Classification",
        "STHoles: A Multidimensional Workload-aware Histogram",
        "Hierarchical Density Estimates for Data Clustering, Visualization, and Outlier Detection",
        "Multi-tactic Distance-based Outlier Detection",
        "QUAD: Quadratic-bound-based Kernel Density Visualization",
        "Fast Augmentation Algorithms for Network Kernel Density Visualization",
        "Anomaly Detection: A Survey",
        "XGBoost: A Scalable Tree Boosting System",
        "Tsunami: A Learned Multi-dimensional Index for Correlated Data and Skewed Workloads",
        "Marviq: Quality-Aware Geospatial Visualization of Range-Selection Queries Using Materialization",
        "Selectivity Estimation for Range Predicates using Lightweight Models",
        "DBSCAN revisited: Mis-claim, Un-fixability, and Approximation",
        "The History of Histograms (Abridged)",
        "A Performance Study of One-dimensional Learned Cardinality Estimation",
        "FastQRE: Fast Query Reverse Engineering",
        "LightGBM: a highly efficient gradient boosting decision tree",
        "Algorithms for Mining Distance-based Outliers in Large Datasets",
        "The Case for Learned Index Structures",
        "LISA: A Learned Index Structure for Spatial Data",
        "Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search on High Dimensional Data‚ÄîExperiments, Analyses, and Improvement",
        "LHist: Towards Learning Multi-dimensional Histogram for Massive Spatial Data",
        "A Nonparametric Estimate of a Multivariate Density Function",
        "Visualizing Data Using t-SNE",
        "Benchmarking Learned Indexes",
        "Rectified linear units improve restricted boltzmann machines",
        "Learning Multi-dimensional Indexes",
        "Distance-based Outlier Detection: Consolidation and Renewed Bearing",
        "Effectively Learning Spatial Indices",
        "Theoretically Optimal and Empirically Efficient R-trees with Strong Parallelizability",
        "Efficient Algorithms for Mining Outliers from Large Data Sets",
        "Introducing a new benchmarked dataset for activity monitoring",
        "Clustering by fast search and find of density peaks",
        "JENGA-A Framework to Study the Impact of Data Errors on the Predictions of Machine Learning Models.",
        "An End-to-End Learning-based Cost Estimator",
        "Learned Cardinality Estimation for Similarity Queries",
        "Mining Distance-based Outliers from Large Databases in any Metric Space",
        "Handbook of Discrete and Computational Geometry",
        "Progress in Outlier Detection Techniques: A Survey",
        "Spatial Online Sampling and Aggregation",
        "Theoretically-efficient and Practical Parallel DBSCAN",
        "Monotonic Cardinality Estimation of Similarity Selection: A Deep Learning Approach",
        "Consistent and Flexible Selectivity Estimation for High-dimensional Data",
        "Smartphone and Smartwatch-based Biometrics using Activities of Daily Living",
        "Deep Unsupervised Cardinality Estimation",
        "An incremental CFS algorithm for clustering large data in industrial internet of things",
        "SPRIG: A Learned Spatial Index for Range and kNN Queries",
        "FLAT: Fast, Lightweight and Accurate Method for Cardinality Estimation",
        "SARS-CoV-2 receptor ACE2 is an interferon-stimulated gene in human airway epithelial cells and is detected in specific cell subsets across tissues"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learned k-NN Distance Estimation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
